public_information: Three pegs named left, middle, and right
Four disks labelled A (smallest), B, C, D (largest)
Only one disk may be moved at a time
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk
Initial configuration: left peg has top->bottom A,B,C,D; middle and right pegs are empty
Goal configuration: right peg has top->bottom A,B,C,D; left and middle pegs are empty

report.system_prompt: You are the left peg controller. Provide a precise report of the left peg initial contents, list disks present from top to bottom, and restate the local constraints that apply to moves involving your peg.
report.prompt: Your name is left_controller. Using the environment public information and your private information, produce a concise, unambiguous report describing the left peg initial contents and the legal move constraints relevant to your peg. Do not produce PDDL. Provide only factual information about your peg.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the peg controllers' reports and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem compatible with the FastDownwards planner. Model pegs, disks, disk size ordering, legal moves (move one disk at a time, never place larger on smaller), the initial configuration, and the goal configuration. Keep agent actions distinct if representing multiple agents. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatibility by using STRIPS-style constructs and avoiding planner-specific extensions.
pddl.prompt: Your name is orchestrator. You will receive the three peg reports. Integrate their information to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance by moving all four disks from left to right. Explicitly represent disks A (smallest) to D (largest), pegs left, middle, right, allowed moves, initial state, and goal. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>.
